title: Sasha and the Apartment Purchase
statementHtml:
Sasha wants to buy an apartment on a street where the houses are numbered from 11 to 109109 from left to right.

There are nn bars on this street, located in houses with numbers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. Note that there might be multiple bars in the same house, and in this case, these bars are considered distinct.

Sasha is afraid that by the time he buys the apartment, some bars may close, but no more than kk bars can close.

For any house with number xx, define f(x)f(x) as the sum of |x−y||x−y| over all open bars yy (that is, after closing some bars).

Sasha can potentially buy an apartment in a house with number xx (where 1≤x≤1091≤x≤109) if and only if it is possible to close at most kk bars so that after that f(x)f(x) becomes minimal among all houses.

Determine how many different houses Sasha can potentially buy an apartment in.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤105,0≤k<n1≤n≤105,0≤k<n) — the number of bars and the maximum number of bars that can close.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the house numbers where the bars are located.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 105105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the number of houses where Sasha can buy an apartment.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, none of the bars can close, so only houses numbered 22 and 33 are suitable. For the house numbered 22, the sum of distances is |2−1|+|2−2|+|2−3|+|2−4|=4|2−1|+|2−2|+|2−3|+|2−4|=4, and for the house numbered 33, the sum of distances is |3−1|+|3−2|+|3−3|+|3−4|=4|3−1|+|3−2|+|3−3|+|3−4|=4. However, for the house numbered 11, the sum of distances will be |1−1|+|1−2|+|1−3|+|1−4|=6|1−1|+|1−2|+|1−3|+|1−4|=6, so the house numbered 11 is not suitable. It can also be proven that Sasha cannot buy apartments in other houses.

In the second test case, the suitable houses are numbered 66 and 77. For Sasha to choose the house numbered 66, it is sufficient that none of the bars close. For Sasha to choose the house numbered 77, the bars in houses 11 and 66 can close. Then the bars will be located in houses numbered 66, 77, and 77.
